markdownRemark.html:
MIDIVal is TypeScript / JavaScript library simplifying communication between MIDI Devices and JavaScript environments. It can run in browsers (that support WebMIDI), Node.js environment and React Native.

It can be used for both reading MIDI Input messages (sent by synthesisers, drum machines, MIDI controllers or messages from DAW) as well as write to MIDI Output (to drive synthesisers, DAW, controllers, etc).

Architecture Overview

The central point of MIDIVal is @midival/core. It provides all the main classes allowing for simple communication with MIDI devices using high-level methods (instead of having to sent low level MIDI messages manually). The core package also provides bindings for WebMIDI so it can be used in the browser right out of the box.

To use MIDIVal in Node.js or React Native, you need to install adapters: @midival/node or @midival/react-native, respectively.

Installation and setup

MIDIVal can be installed from Node Package Manager using npm or yarn command:

yarn add @midival/core

Installation for Node.js

To use MIDIVal in Node.js environment you need to install @midival/node adapter and node midi library:

yarn add @midival/core @midival/node midi

Installation for React Native

To use MIDIVal in React Native environment, you need to install @midival/react-native adapter:

yarn add @midival/core @midival/react-native

Getting MIDI In and Out Devices

Once the library is installed you can use it to connect and list MIDI devices.

import { MIDIVal } from "@midival/core"; MIDIVal.connect() .then(access => { console.log("Input Devices", access.inputs); console.log("Output Devices", access.outputs); });

Each of the inputs and outputs consists of name, manufacturer and id allowing you to narrow down on the interface you are interested in.

Connecting to MIDI Input Device

Once you selected input you want to connect you, you need to instantiate MIDIValInput out of it. Thanks to that you will be able to listen to input messages. The following example takes first input device and listens to all MIDI On messages.

MIDIVal.connect() .then(access => { if (!access.inputs) { console.warn("No inputs yet"); return; } const input = new MIDIValInput(access.inputs[0]); input.onAllNoteOn(message => { console.log("Note On", message.note, message.velocity); }); });

Connecting to MIDI Output Device

After choosing which MIDI Output device you want to connect to, you can instantiate MIDIValOutput and start sending messages like folowing:

MIDIVal.connect() .then(access => { if (!access.outputs) { console.warn("No outputs yet"); return; } const output = new MIDIValOutput(access.outputs[0]); output.sendNoteOn(64, 127); setTimeout(() => { output.sendNoteOff(64); }, 200); });
